description: Beards & Beaks is Microsoft's first in-house produced game for the Windows Phone 7. The game operates largely on a touchscreen flicking gesture, flinging gnomes either at jewels (which are carried away to win most levels) or the enemies - square-bodied crows. The game has something of a real-time strategy sense to it, in the command of troops and usage of specialized troop types as the game progresses. It also shows some similarities to Pikmin in its mechanics and troop movements. In various levels, game goals range from collecting jewels to deathmatch-style fights to capture-the-flag encounters.
title: Beards & Beaks

description:
Rune Legend is a brick-placement puzzle game where differently shaped runestones need to be fit into the gameboards, using spatial imagination. Players have to drag the runestones over the gameboard and find the layout which covers the whole gameboard without any holes and overlaps to complete each level. The theme and background story is based on Norse mythology. As a follower of the God Odin, the main character undertakes the journey through fantasy worlds with many legendary figures.

The game offers various game modes. The very heart of game lies in 24-level story mode that recounts the original Norse myth about runestones and their magical power. Other options are time and number of actions challenges, hotseat multiplayer and free play.
title: Rune Legend

description: Taptics is a Metro-themed Simon clone for Windows Phone. Players tap tiles on the screen based on a random order generated for each level, and are penalized for each incorrect tap. Levels increase in difficulty by lengthening the number of tiles in the "pattern", and are timed. The game ends when the level timer runs down or the player makes three incorrect taps in a single level. The game features an online leaderboard via Scoreloop, allowing players to compare their scores against others.
title: Taptics

description: This is a voice-driven game that takes the form of a story set in Shanghai. An accident has happened, and the player must figure out what happened as well as relearn the Chinese language. As the player interacts with and remembers different words (objects), new memories and scenes are revealed. The game makes heavy use of visual images to help the player reinforce their knowledge of Chinese words, and forces the player to repeat practical words and phrases in order to progress in the story (and in their personal learning progress). There are also other features in the game that allow the player to practice specific words and reference them quickly.
title: TAWKABLE Chinese: Sketches of China

description:
In Fusion: Sentient, the player is a young machinist who finds himself embroiled in an evil plot to which he must uncover the truth. The story takes him battling across the universe, plowing through hordes of sentients with his own, hand-picked squad.

Fusion: Sentient is a real-time, strategy game in which the player controls a squad of mechs, called sentients. The player can choose a custom squad, level the sentients and equip them with weapons looted through battle. These sentients can then be sent to or received from Fusion Genesis.
title: Fusion: Sentient

description:
Bejeweled Live is a version of the Bejeweled series for Windows Phone. It is largely identical to the early game in the series Bejeweled as it does not contain any of the new game modes or gameplay mechanics from the contemporary versions for other platforms. It is played on an 8x8 field where colored jewels need to be lined up horizontally or vertically by swapping them, with at least three of a kind. After the match the jewels code and the board is replenished from the top with new jewels.

The three game modes are Classic, Race the Clock and Endless Play. Classic is a series of levels presented as an endless mode, Race the Clock introduces a time system, and Endless Play is like Classic, but without the division into levels. A hint button provides suggestions when stuck. The 'Live' part of the title refers to the integration with Xbox Live for leaderboards.
title: Bejeweled: Live

description:
Bejeweled Live+ is the second game in the Bejeweled series for Windows Phone, following the earlier Bejeweled Live. Unlike the first game that borrowed from the early Bejeweled titles, this version is based on Bejeweled 3.

The player is presented with a board filled with gems of different colours. The aim of the game is to remove gems from the board by swapping adjacent gems so that a chain of three or more gems is created. New gems will then be generated at the top of the screen and fall down in the empty spaces. This can lead to a chain reaction when gems fall down and create new matches. It is possible to continue swapping gems during a chain reaction. There are some special gems. Flame gems are created from a match of four gems and explode when matched, thereby removing surrounding gems. A match of five gems will create a hypercube which can be matched with any adjacent gem and then destroy all gems of that colour. Star gems are created by T- or L-shaped matches and destroy all gems that are right, left, up and down of the it.

The game modes included in this version are Butterflies, Classic, Diamond Mine, Lightning and Zen. It does not include Ice Storm, Poker or Quest. Also missing is the Blitz game mode that was made available as a separate game called Bejeweled Blitz for several platforms. The game includes achievements and leadersboards tied to the Xbox Live service and progress in the game modes adds up to a global player level.

Classic is a series of levels presented as an endless mode. There is no timer or special objectives. Players make matches until no more moves are possible. Diamond Mine is played against the clock and matches need to be made to destroy dirt at the bottom. All dirt needs to be removed before time runs out. By digging through the dirt gold and treasures can be unearthed for extra points. Butterflies introduces a spider near the top of the screen that eats butterflies. The goal of this mode is to keep butterfly gems away from the spider by creating matches. Lightning is a timed mode reminiscent of Bejeweled Blitz where 60 seconds are provided to create as many matches as possible. By matching time gems additional seconds can be won. Zen is like the endless Classic mode, but without the division into levels. That mode also include options to change the background music to nature sounds, textual mantras can be selected to pop up and a breathing modulation display can be enabled. The latter shows a line on-screen, raising and dropping slowly, to help regulate a peaceful way of breathing.
title: Bejeweled: Live+

description:
Techno Kitten Adventure! is a one-button game. The cat automatically moves forward, but also constantly falls downwards (this results in a diagonal movement). By tapping, the player can reverse this: now the cat moves upwards. The player needs to avoid the sparkling stars which form upwards/downwards boundaries as well as obstacles in the way. Each survived second the point counter fills up; the goal is to earn as many points as possible. This is not only required to gather a place on the high-score list, but also unlocks additional kittens for the level.

Each level also has a large amount of animations in the fore- and background, e.g. pictures, ships, other flying animals or flashing colours. Those are designed to distract the player from the real dangers. The levels itself are randomly generated and the gameplay challenges are identical between levels. They have still significant differences because every one features different themes, cat characters and techno tunes.

This version includes the following levels:

  • Cloud Pack
  • Dream Pack
  • Lava Pack
  • Popaganda Pack
title: Techno Kitten Adventure!

description:
Praetor is a turn based game an the predecessor of Imperator. The story is told in a campain witch does also include the tutorial.

Similar to CCG (Collectible Card Game) games the cards in the players deck represent creatures, items, sorceries etc. which the player uses in the battle. Before a battle the player has to choose the cards he wants to use, since the number of cards in the deck is limited. In addition to the summoned creatures the player is represented itself as a character on the battlefield. The player has to choose one of the four classes (warrior, sorcerer, conqueror or leader). Cards are used by drawing them from the deck and playing them onto the board. Battles take place on a hexagonal grid map. By winning battles the player gets additional cards.

Each card played does costs an individual amount of energy to play and does include information like strength, health, move, energy cost, specific type of needed energy or attributes. There are five kinds of energy: earth, water, air, fire and general. At the beginning of each turn the player regains some energy. The number of the regained energy is affected by i.e. emplacements or special creatures. Left energy of the previous turn will not be transfered.

Some type of terrain effectuate the stats of creatures standing on the tile (i.e.armor penalty, reduced movement) and palisades offer some kind of protection.

The number of damage taken is calculated by the attackers strength and the defenders protection. There isn't any random or luck value that could influence the result. The attacker deals the damage to the defender first. If the defending creature survives the attack it does automatically retaliate. Attacking and retaliating does cost energy. Most creatures can attack only once per turn.

The cards are classified into six groups:

  • Creatures: They are, beside the main character itself, the soldiers on the battlefield.
  • Enchantments: They are used to modify the status of creatures for several turns (i.e. gaining more attack points, slow down an enemy).
  • Sorceries: They are similar to enchantments, but their effect is singular.
  • Emplacements: They are similar to enchantments, but they do not affect a specific creature but creatures around the emplacement.
  • Equipment: They modify the the attributes or basis values of the main character.
  • Allies: A creature that appear straight at the beginning of the battle, so it doesn't need to be summoned.
title: Praetor

description: Hydro Thunder: GO is an entry in the Hydro Thunder racing series with powerboats in a futuristic setting. The game contains nine levels entirely new for the series, with environments including a dinosaur island, a UFO invasion, a tropical pirate ship battle and ice caverns on the arctic circle. By progressing through the game up to twelve boats can be unlocked, with classics such as Miss Behave, Rad Hazard and Tinytanic. There is also a separate Hydro Blaze expert game mode with an additional, more challenging track. The game supports online multiplayer.
title: Hydro Thunder: GO

description: Pinball League: The Juggler is a single-player, single-table 3D pinball game for mobile devices. The theme of the table is based on The juggler, a painting by Chronis Dardalis. The painting serves as the table artwork.
title: Pinball League: The Juggler

description: Farkle! WP is a simple 2 player dice game which can be played against another player or against a computer. At the beginning of the player's turn they roll six dice, then set aside one or more scoring dice to accumulate points (singular 5s and 1s, 3 or more of the same number, 3 different pairs of matching numbers, and 1 of every number). The player can then choose to roll the remaining dice, or if they more than the minimum amount of points needed (300 by default) they can end their turn and add those accumulated points to their total score. If the player manages to set aside all six dice they can re-roll all of them to add to their accumulated points. If the player rolls the dice and there are no scoring dice, the player's turn ends and they lose the points they accumulated that turn. Once a player's total score has reached the win threshold (10,000 by default), the apposing player has one last turn to accumulate enough points to overtake their opponent.
title: Farkle! WP

description:
The Path of Kara is a match-three puzzle game in which the player takes on the role of Kara, a young shaman, who is tasked to save her island by Edda, the tribe elder.

The game is played on a hexagonal grid where matching three or more identical adjacent items will remove them and spawn new items at the top of the grid. Bonus items are available, like a bomb that destroys nearby items, or a potion that grants extra time to complete the puzzle. Some levels require the player to make matches next to a special item or over specific tiles a certain number of times.

Kara's quest unfolds over 70 levels with varied objectives and challenges, introduced by dialogues with the characters she will meet along the way. Each chapter of the story concludes with a special boss fight level.
title: The Path of Kara

description:
Dragon is a side-scrolling game where the player controls a dragon flying inside a cave, with the objective of going as far as possible without hitting the floor, the ceiling, or the obstacles in between.

The dragon flies forward automatically and the player can only interact with it by tapping or pressing the screen to make it fly higher, or releasing to let it fly lower.

There are four difficulty levels available which also affect the game's color palette.
title: Dragon

description: This runner platform game puts a single player in control of a penguin, whose job it is to discover the secret of a group of artifacts that have crash-landed in his Arctic abode. Along the way, the penguin must avoid (and jump to kill) enemies and collect as many coins and artifacts as possible to complete the level. The penguin moves on its own, but the player can tap the screen to make it jump, and drag to make it slide or dive.
title: Penguin Adventure Run

description: Triangle Head's Adventure is a short, comedic point-and-click adventure game that plays out a bizarre scenario. In this case, the player character is a young man who suffers a horrible curse: at every full moon, his head is transformed into a triangle. He has now become Triangle Head and has to get ready for a date, who will be coming to his house in two minutes. It is the player's objective to look around the house in this time limit and find a way of hiding the main character's abnormal head shape before the date arrives. You can look and interact with items while trying to come up with the perfect disguise!
title: Triangle Head's Adventure

description:
Toy Soldiers: Boot Camp offers Windows Phone conversions of three of the shooting gallery mini-games from the Windows and Xbox 360 game Toy Soldiers: Cold War.

In Cardboard Theatre, the player must destroy as many targets as possible in 60 seconds by guiding missiles.

In Flyswatter, the player must shoot down as many houseflies as possible in 60 seconds.

In Thread the Needle, the player must guide a missile through holes in rotating discs as it travels down a tunnel.

In all three mini-games, the controls are as follow: swipe the screen to aim, tap the fire button to shoot. In some games, the fire button can be slid up and down to change the speed of the missile.

The game offers Xbox Live achievements and is linked to its console and PC counterpart by the presence in the latter of a mobile leaderboard.
title: Toy Soldiers: Boot Camp

description:
IonBallEX is a Breakout-inspired game with a steampunk theme. The player is tasked with clearing all bricks on the playfield by hitting a ball with a paddle located at the bottom of the screen. Some bricks release power-ups when hit, with the red ones actually affecting the player negatively.

The game features a XP progression system that lets players upgrade their paddle by spending the XP they have earned on previous levels. Possible upgrades include for instance enhanced shield, XP multiplier, paddle size, or ball damage.

The game contains 35 levels, with a boss contraption to defeat every few levels.

sample_screenshots.caption: Boss at the end of level 5

title: IonBallEX

description:
Fable: Coin Golf is inspired by British pub games. It takes place in the Fable universe and loosely follows the Fable III story arc across three chapters, each taking place in a different region.

On each level, the player must maneuver their puck around obstacles and enemies to reach the target zone (called the 'Pillar of Light'), using as few shots as possible to maximize their score. Levels sometimes contain power-ups that give the puck certain powers if run over, like killing enemies or building bridges to cross rivers. A base score is required to progress to the next level and unlocks a bronze medal. Higher scores unlock silver and gold medals.

Gold coins can be collected by getting the puck in contact with them and can be transferred to Fable III on Xbox 360 and Windows. Completing each chapter also unlocks an exclusive weapon in the Traitor's Keep downloadable content pack for Fable III.

sample_screenshots.caption: Level 12 showing a power-up that allows the puck to cut trees.

title: Fable: Coin Golf
